_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1) Environmental, Health and Safety Policy

The accidental release prevention and emergency response programs at the Lucent Technologies Microelectronics Group facility in Reading, Pennsylvania are fully supported by senior management.  The following Environmental, Health and Safety Policy is supported by Lucent senior management.

The Microelectronics Group of Lucent Technologies is committed to the protection and preservation of the environment and a safe and healthy workplace for all employees.  It is our intent to be recognized by our customers, employees, community, and stakeholders as a responsible business committed to continual improvement in environmental, health and safety (EH&S) management in all business activities.  To that end we shall:

7 Establish objectives and targets that consider environmental aspects and health and safety issues as an integral part of our business decision making process.
7 Comply with all applicable laws, regulations, permits, Lucent worldwide standards and other requirements to which we subscribe.
7 Provide a workplace which supports prevention of injury and illness by fostering a safety and health culture that encourages employee participation and individual accountability.
7 Develop employee knowledge and understanding of EH&S issues related to job functions.
7 Promote conservation of resources in design, manufacture and use of our products by reusing, recycling and by adopting processes which conserve the use of raw materials, energy and water.
7 Promote pollution prevention by striving to reduce the generation of waste from existing and future operations.
7 Communicate this EH&S policy to all employees and make it available to the public.
7 Engage the participation of the communities in which we do business.

Implementation of this policy is a primary management objective and the responsibility of all employees.  This policy supports the Lucent Technologies EH&S Policy.

2)  Description of the facility and the regulated s

ubstances handled

The Lucent Technologies facility in Reading, Pennsylvania (Lucent-Reading) is engaged in the manufacture of electronic components for telecommunications equipment.  The products manufactured at the facility include integrated circuits and optoelectronic devices.  The facility's products are used in a wide variety of communications equipment, including telephones, switching, and transmission equipment, data processing equipment, and computers.

The facility includes multiple clean rooms and product assembly and test areas of various levels of cleanliness and electrostatic shock discharge control necessary to manufacturing.   The two chemicals under consideration for the Lucent-Reading Risk Management Program (40 CFR Part 68), hydrogen chloride (RMP Program 3 process) and trichlorosilane (RMP Program 1 process), are used in the polysilicon reactors on the second floor of the facility.  Hydrogen chloride from the bulk system is used in the epitaxial reactors on the second floor of the facility.

Hydrogen chloride (HCl) is stored as a liquefied gas under pressure in two tube trailers housed in a masonry building at the southeast corner of the facility (Building 39).  Each tube trailer includes seven (7) 3,000-pound, stainless steel, horizontal cylinders of HCl when completely full.  The maximum quantity of HCl stored in the Risk Management Program (RMP)-covered process is 42,000 pounds (14 tubes at 3,000 pounds each).

The bulk HCl system (the RMP-covered process - Program 3) includes the following major safety systems to minimize the chances of release of HCl to the atmosphere:
7 Fourteen (14) stainless steel cylinders with pneumatic isolation valves, 13 of which are normally closed
7 Corrosion resistant double-walled piping network, including Hastelloy inner piping and stainless steel outer piping, with a monitored static vacuum between the inner and outer walls
7 Masonry building with HCl-resistant wall and floor coatings, sloped floors, and a spil

l containment sump to house the HCl tube trailers and high pressure control manifold
7 Emergency release multi-venturi scrubber containing 20% sodium hydroxide to treat any HCl release prior to release to atmosphere
7 Gas detection and alarm systems which trigger multiple shut-down and emergency scrubbing actions upon detection of HCl 
7 Valve manifold boxes for isolation, containment and control of gas distribution systems

Upon completion in May 2000, the bulk trichlorosilane (TCS) system will include two on-site mobil ISO containers, for a combined maximum storage of 42,500 pounds of liquid TCS for the RMP-covered process.  The container head space will be pressurized by argon for delivery of the liquid TCS to the process reactors through a double-walled, stainless steel piping system.  The bulk TCS system will be located south of the bulk hydrogen chloride system. 

The bulk TCS system (the RMP-covered process - Program 1) will include the following major safety systems to minimize the chances of release of TCS to the atmosphere:
7 Stainless steel mobile ISO containers covered by 2-hour fire-rated insulation and argon-pressurized head space for liquid delivery
7 Containment dike designed to contain greater than 110% of one (1) ISO container
7 Fire detection and foam fire suppression systems
7 Gas detection and alarm systems which will trigger multiple shut-down actions upon detection of TCS
7 Corrosion resistant double-walled piping network, including stainless steel inner and outer piping, with a monitored static vacuum between the inner and outer walls
7 Valve manifold boxes for isolation, containment and control of liquid distribution systems

3)  Worst-case release scenarios and alternative release scenarios

The worst-case and alternative release scenarios evaluated for the hydrogen chloride Program 3 process were as follows:

7 Worst-case release scenario - 3,000 pounds of HCl contained as a gas liquefied by pressure in a single cylinder is released over a

10-minute period into the masonry building (passive mitigation system) which houses the HCl tube trailers.  Using RMP*Comp, the distance to the toxic endpoint of 0.030 mg/L was estimated to be 1.90 miles (10,032 feet).  The estimated residential population within the distance to endpoint is 30,000.  The public receptors within the distance to endpoint include schools, residences, hospitals, recreation areas, and commercial, office and industrial areas.  There are no environmental receptors, as defined in the regulations, within the distance to endpoint.

The risk of occurrence of the worst-case scenario is effectively zero, since the bulk HCl system has numerous active and passive mitigation measures and administrative controls in place to prevent the release of any HCl into the environment.  Some of the major control systems designed to prevent the release of HCl are listed in the previous section (Section 2 - Description of the facility and the regulated substances handled).

7 Alternative release scenario - The rupture disk for a single cylinder of HCl fails and releases 3,000 pounds of HCl over a 15 minute period into the masonry building (passive mitigation system) which houses the HCl tube trailers.  The emergency release scrubber treats the release such that the maximum concentration of HCl in the outlet gas stream from the scrubber is 25 parts per million (ppm).  Using RMP*Comp, the distance to the toxic endpoint of 0.030 mg/L was estimated to be 0.10 miles (528 feet).  No residential population, no public receptors and no environmental receptors exist within the distance to endpoint.

The risk of the rupture disk failing at the Reading facility is effectively zero, since the HCl tubes are filled and tested off site, under the control of the HCl supplier.  

The worst-case release scenario evaluated for the trichlorosilane Program 1 process was as follows:

Worst-case release scenario - 42,500 pounds of trichlorosilane, a flammable liquid, contained in a si

ngle ISO container is released and is involved in a vapor cloud explosion.  Using RMP*Comp, the distance to the overpressure endpoint of 1 PSI was estimated to be 0.10 miles (528 feet).  No residential population, no public receptors and no environmental receptors exist within the distance to endpoint.

The risk of occurrence of the worst-case scenario is effectively zero, since the bulk TCS system has numerous active and passive mitigation measures and administrative controls in place to prevent the release of any TCS into the environment.  Some of the major control systems designed to prevent the release of TCS are listed in the previous section (Section 2 - Description of the facility and the regulated substances handled).

4)  General accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps

The bulk hydrogen chloride system is currently in compliance with OSHA's regulation 29 CFR 1910.119 "Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals."  The bulk trichlorosilane system is currently under design and construction.  The bulk trichlorosilane system will comply with the OSHA PSM regulations.

The chemical-specific prevention steps are summarized in Section 2 of this Executive Summary. 

5)  Five-year accident history

There have been no reportable accidents at Lucent-Reading involving hydrogen chloride or trichlorosilane during the five-year period ending in May 1999.

6)  Emergency response program

Lucent-Reading maintains an internal Emergency Response Team (ERT) in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.156, 1910.120 and 1910. 146.  The ERT is led by an Incident Commander, and a number of functional members or teams who take direction from the Incident Commander.  The ERT has lead responsibility for on-site emergency response to such incidents as fires or spills, until offsite emergency services arrive (if applicable).

The ERT includes a Hazardous Materials/Fire Brigade.  There are ERT members across three shifts. Members of the ERT receive t

raining in the containment and control of hazardous materials and/or waste.  They are trained in the use of personal protective equipment and will work with our Security and Medical personnel to minimize the likelihood and/or severity of injuries to our employees.

ERT members receive certification in First Aid and CPR and are trained to: 
7 Technician Level under 1910.120
7 Structural Firefighter under 1910.156
7 Emergency Responder Level - Confined Space Entry 1910.146

They receive training in the meaning of our alarm systems, their locations and activation methods of emergency shut-off systems.  ERT members participate in regular drills and exercises including outside agency participation as appropriate. 

Lucent-Reading maintains a twenty-four hour security office, which serves as a central receiving point for the emergency notification process.  Once notified of a potential emergency, the Security Control Room Officer contacts the appropriate Lucent personnel.  In addition to contacting facility personnel in the event of a leak or spill of significance, the plan requires the notification of external agencies and offices. 

On-site notifications are conducted through use of telephone, radios, and pagers.  Notification lists reflect home and work telephone numbers, and pager and cell phone numbers, as applicable.  Immediate notification has been defined as notification within 15 minutes of knowledge of a release.

Lucent-Reading's emergency and crisis management structure is designed to reflect three primary activities, which must be performed in response to a potentially significant incident.  These activities are:
7 on-site management of the emergency response to the incident;
7 management support to the on-site emergency response; and
7 management of the incident's consequences to Lucent-Reading and the surrounding community.

7)  Planned changes to improve safety

Lucent-Reading is currently completing the design and installation of a bulk trichlorosilane sy

stem.  The system is scheduled to be fully operational in May 2000.  A summary of the major safety systems for the bulk TCS is provided in Section 2 of this Executive Summary.  This bulk TCS system is replacing the current storage and use of TCS in stainless steel drums.
